nodes.bodyText: This information has been useful to me when debugging these flakey tests, and I suspect customer's will appreciate this too
This will log if a message is a twin subscription message, method subscription message, etc.

The commit message explains this further, but Android SDKs return -1 when inputStream.read(...) reads no bytes. JDKs return 0 though. For consistency between JDK and android SDK, we shouldn't use this return value

This status class was used to simplify twin callbacks, but it hid useful information for failure cases. Knowing why a callback fired back with an unsuccessful state is important to log when the test fails
only return the newly created property
Again, only send the reported properties that belong to this thread. See above for why
how is this going to affect the callback? is this considered a breaking change?
This is in the test code, so it isn't a breaking change, no
ah, the file path threw me off
this method is no longer doing what its name implies does it? it's creating and returning a new set
It still does what it says. It only returns the property that was updated, but that returned property did already exist

By the way, this and other methods always return Set even when only one property is in the set. The reason for this is so that the test method can use this returned value directly when calling "sendReportedProperties(Set)" instead of building the set after calling this method
I see, so it updates the existing and also returns a new set as a return value. fair.
